It would be great to be able to filter the report by a time window, especially for reporting.  Or being able to use it to zoom in on a part of a plan. For instance I would like to be able to find out what percentage of effort was spent on themes for a certain time window (like Q1, Q2, etc).

There are two hacks I can think of:
-Add a release to all streams and assign anything that starts in Q1 to that release.  Then do reporting by the release.

-Label initiatives with a prefix (like Q1-Go to Moon) and then filter by that prefix.  

Both of these are really approximate as releases or initiatives bleed into Q2 from Q1.

Or is there another way to do this?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-357].
  {panel}

We'd like to be able to group the Epic Roadmap views by additional criteria. Today the only grouping options are None, Team and Member. We'd like to also group by things like Product or Delivery Mechanism (Web, Desktop, Mobile, etc.).

Here is the use cases: 
* We want to show a roadmap by Product, but currently our teams are not a 1 to 1 relationship with Product. We could have more than 1 team on a product or share teams across products. We're currently using Team to represent Product for a product roadmap, but would love to use team as the actual scrum teams to take advantage of the capacity planning elements.
* We also have a need to show roadmaps by Delivery Mechanism as we have goals of investing in some more than others.

I'm sure as we use this, we'll think of more uses. The ultimate would be to allow us to customize which fields to group on and allow multiple Epic views to exist simultaneously with different groupings.

Thanks!

[~aentler]
fields.summary: Additional ways of grouping Epic roadmap/Gantt chart view in Jira Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-198].
  {panel}

We are now using Portfolio to plan a cross-team roadmap and have discovered an issue with importing stories into an Epic.

We use Epics to describe each Feature (and grouped into higher Initiatives) and the Epic can be worked on by one or more teams.  Our process working with Epics and Stories via Portfolio goes as follows.

1. Epics are defined in JIRA
2. Epics are imported into Portfolio
3. Epic estimates are entered into Portfolio representing the best guess per team to allow long-term planning.
4. As each Epic is further defined and gets closer to the top of the plan, the teams created their stories (in JIRA) under the Epic
5. The teams then estimate and allocate story points to the stories (in JIRA)
6. Once all teams have created and pointed all stories for the Epic, they are imported into Portfolio, replacing all Epic estimates with the total of the story points.

We have discovered a problem between steps 4,5 and 6 above.  If we ask the teams to create stories and before step 6 is complete and Update plan is run, Portfolio will try to replace the Epic estimate with 0, which I presume is the total of all stories.

For example:
*Epic impacts App and Server teams
*Epic estimates are App(20), Server (30)
*Server team add 3 stories under the Epic (no points)
* Update plan is run and all Epic estimates are replaced with 0

Is this expected behaviour (and therefore a problem with our process) or a bug?
fields.summary: Epic estimates overwritten on import by un-estimated stories

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create a Plan on JIRA Portfolio

h3. Current behaviour

This error is displayed:
{noformat}
Exception timestamp: 23:05:13 GMT-0500 (CDT)
http://localhost:8080/download/resources/com.radiantminds.roadmaps-jira:view-resources/scripts/page-roadmap/script-optimized.js :TypeError: 'undefined' is not an object (evaluating 't.size'
Line# 26866, Col# undefined. Detailed stacktrace not available in your browser.
{noformat}

h3. Expected behaviour

Display JPO normally without the error.

Obs. We didn't notice any loose of functionality, so it seems you can close the error and continue working.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-250].
  {panel}

The current Themes functionality allows each Story to be tagged with at most one Theme. The explanation in the doco is that this avoids the problem of double-counting effort.
The trouble with this constraint is that there are cases where double-counting is exactly what I want to be able to do.
To demonstrate by extreme, say my plan consists of just one Story - "Deliver technical report". Say my business objectives are represented as two themes - "Satisfy customers" and "Grow knowledge-base". Why shouldn't I be able to assign both themes to the story and then have my Themes report show a 50/50 split?
In other words, when a Story is assigned to two themes, just add that story's effort to both themes and let the normalisation-across-themes takes care of it when charted.

Note that this suggestion is independent of JPO-249.
fields.summary: Allow Story to contribute to multiple Themes
View labels in JIRA Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-365].
  {panel}

While utilizing Story Points for Portfolio planning and performing a plan update, it automatically sets Completed stories to 0.

This is unexpected behavior, and has ramifications for users of JIRA Agile when a Story's points are changed mid-sprint
In addition, our users are disgruntled when a Story that they completed which they thought difficult was set to 0. It tells them that story wasn't difficult.

We use Story Points as "Difficulty", which translates to "Time Estimated". We have never used Story Points as "Time Remaining".

We have the existing work-around of undoing all of the estimated changes, this is time consuming.

As a suggestion, allow an option to disable setting Completed task's Story Points field to 0.
Instead, have the Plan understand that completed tasks have an "effective" story point of 0, without changing the field.

This setting should probably be the default for users of Story Points.
fields.summary: Option for "Update from Date" to not set Completed task's Story Points to 0

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-258].
  {panel}

In the Epics backlog, I have some projects that I would like to keep in our backlog, but that we aren't prioritizing yet.  This helps to keep these projects on our radar when we are choosing which projects to prioritize.  Currently, I manually set these to be in the "Later" release, but I'd also like to keep them at the bottom of our backlog to unclutter our view of the scheduled projects.  

Unfortunately, if I add epics to use the normal "Create Epic" button, it puts the newly created epic below all of those items that are in the "Later" release.  Thus, it would be great to have some of the following:
- Instead of requiring me to drag and drop (which can be finicky when dragging to the bottom of the list), it would be nice to also be able to manually edit the priority number (i.e. type in "5").
- Expose an option like in Jira Agile backlog, where I can right click and then click "Send to bottom of backlog."
- Allow me to use command/shift click to highlight multiple rows that I can then drag as a group.
- Or, best of all, allow me to keep all of my "Later" items in a specific grouping that sticks to the bottom of the backlog.  It would make sense that if I'm specifically scheduling something for "Later" that it would be at the bottom of the backlog anyhow.
fields.summary: Make it easier to manage "Later" items

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, when you perform a wrong move of  *update from date* or *Apply updates to projects* you have no chance to retrieve your previous state.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a reset button or similar functionality to revert to previous state/changes

h3. Workaround 
Update from date : You can just set the *update from date* date to the past if you did something wrong.
Apply updates to projects : Need to restore your JIRA back prior to the changes
fields.summary: reset "update from date" and "Apply updates to projects" to previous state/changes

Sub-tasks should be supported in Portfolio and should also be displayed in the backlog table as child elements of stories. This would allow for a better JIRA integration. At the moment, Portfolio does not really have a notion of sub-tasks, their estimates are considered in the 'Update from date...' estimate suggestions, but they are not respected when syncing estimates back to JIRA, which then potentially adds the sub-tasks estimates to the parent story.

Thus, it is desirable to manage sub-tasks of stories in the same way as stories are treated within epics.

As a JIRA Portfolio administrator
I would like disable "Everybody" as permission access to new plans in my platform
so that authorized users must be input on a per-plan basis and then the list of plans for every user only includes the ones strictly interesting for him/her.

Even though the option "Private (only me)" is the default in the creation dialog, many users may be tempted to use "Everybody", as it suggests an easy access for colleagues. In large instances, using "Everybody" creates long lists of uninteresting plans for most users.

Having or not "Everybody" in the plan creation dialog could ideally be set as an administrative feature at platform level.
As a complementary feature, plans could allow admins to turn them back to be "Private (only me)"

I understand why the numbered priority of 1,2,3,N exists but sometimes (many times) it doesn't matter, and I'd rather say that all of these epics are equally important and I'd rather you optimize only for any dependencies that exist. But I realize that may not be the way that everyone works or thinks.

So here's my thought: add an option under the settings called something like this:

*Prioritization Constraint*
* *On* - The current Portfolio Operation for Epics and Stories
* *Off* - Makes Epics and Stories behave like Initiatives by having no priority
* *Mixed* - Allows for the priority column to have items that have no priority together at the bottom and also set priority numbers for items

'Apply update to projects' allows the creation of issue links based on the issue link types configured in JIRA. At the moment, the issue link type has to be set up in the following way in order to be created correctly (this is only an example, the wording can be adapted to your likes, of course):

*Name* // *Outward Description* // *Inward Description*
_Dependency_ // _blocks_ // _depends on_

That is, the outward description has to describe the blocking aspect of the relation while the inward description describes the depending / blocked by aspect. Issue links can be configured as described [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+Issue+Linking].

In order to make it easier for users to get issue links created the way they want, Portfolio should allow to configure the direction of the issue links created.
fields.summary: Allow to configure issue link type direction for Portfolio dependencies

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-343].
  {panel}

*Summary*
When using the "update from date" functionality, completed items have their story point estimate removed on the JIRA issues. The portfolio keeps the original estimate, but losing the estimate on JIRA issues is causing problems with JIRA reports as the story points are completely removed.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Import a story with story points into JIRA portfolio
# Set the story in JIRA to "Closed"
# In JIRA portfolio, run the "Update from date" action using the current date
# Find the story and JIRA and note that it's story points have been removed
# Go to the JIRA "version" report and note that the story points have also been removed here, which skews the version report

*Expected Behavior*
Story points should never be removed from the JIRA issues when marked as complete in JIRA portfolio. It is desirable to keep the points for history within JIRA, and also to properly populate the JIRA reports.
fields.summary: Allow disabling estimate suggestions in "Update from date"

{quote}users with this role are not permitted to update issues in JIRA projects from within JIRA Portfolio.
{quote}
What this does is restrict the ability for an user to [publish updates from Portfolio back to JIRA's projects|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAPortfolioServer/Publish+Updates+to+Linked+Projects], but a [synchronisation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAPortfolioServer/Synchronization+Settings] will still occur.

This may cause confusion to users that expect JIRA Portfolio to not affect JIRA's issues.
h5. Workaround

Disable automatic synchronisation
 * go to _Plan > Configure > Synchronization > Keep backlog items in sync_
 * uncheck all the checkboxes.

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 24 March 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!
 
Thanks,
Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

Currently there are quite a number of customer requesting integration between JIRA Portfolio and JIRA Agile.

For example, version created in JIRA Agile can be synchronise to JIRA Portfolio so that they won't need to create again.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-476].
  {panel}

I would like to use a Portfolio plan to define a single set of Releases and be able to easily spread this information on a number of JIRA projects.

Today, we can import JIRA Versions to create Portfolio Releases or link Versions to Releases.
In a plan, backlog items are dispatched across these Releases, but we can only "apply" the release to a JIRA issue if a corresponding Version exists in corresponding JIRA project.

it would be good if the *"Apply updates to projects" could automatically create Versions* required, perhaps asking confirmation to the user, *whenever no existing version matches the release* (name, start/end) being applied.

Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!

Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

When I import issues in Jira Portfolio, I would like to import assignees that already exist on Jira tasks and user stories. 

Some fields are already filled when we "Import issues" : Parent epics and releases. It would be great to also have the assignee filled because very often, when we create tasks in Jira, we already know who will have to work on each task (but we don't know when). And the problem is that when you import dozens of tasks in Portfolio, that were already assigned in Jira, you have to reassign (to force the assignment) all these tasks manually in Portfolio (and so you have to make the assignment job twice).

So, the "import issues" panel could allow to have more columns such as "Assignee" and why not "Sprint" (because sometimes, when importing a task in Portfolio, we already know in which sprint we want to affect this task).

Thank you.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-190].
  {panel}

When using Kanban team plan, there have been a number of instances when Portfolio suggests both a release Start Date and End Date in the past, which is impossible to achieve.

Some specific instances when this occurred were:

1. On 18 Nov 2014, imported issue into epic, selected 'release name - calculate' when importing.  Start and End Dates were returned as 3 Nov 2014 and 6 Nov 2014 respectively. Note that the imported JIRA issue did not have any due dates on it.

2. On 22 Jan 2015, clicking 'Calculate' in the Release drop-down menu in either an Epic or Initiative returned Start Date of 3 Nov 2014 and End Date of 3 Nov 2014.

In both cases, the jobs were small - a matter of 3-5 hours. It's curious that both examples returned 3 Nov 2014, although I'm not sure if this is a red herring?

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

{code}
Exception timestamp: 1431545652817

java.lang.RuntimeException :error in variable slot function {code}

Error when assigning team members to stage. 

h2. Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new scrum plan: “Test Plan”
2. Configure Stages and Skills
* Stage 1
** Skill 11
** Skill 12
** Skill 13

* Stage 2
* * Skill 21
* * Skill 22
* * Skill 23

3. Create Team and assign some members
* Team 1

4. Import backlog
5. Assign Stages to Team (find screen-shot)

Click on "Recalculate" and get the following error message.

{noformat}
Exception timestamp: 1431545652817

java.lang.RuntimeException :error in variable slot function

  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.trafo.teams.common.sprints.VariableScrumWorkSlots.findInIrregulars:69
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.trafo.teams.common.sprints.VariableScrumWorkSlots.getSlotOrNextForTimeStep:50
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.scheduling.data.resources.ResourceGroup.getSlotOrNextForTimeStep:123
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.retrafo.stats.ScheduleStatisticsProvider.getPartialSlotData:79
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.retrafo.stats.ScheduleStatisticsProvider.calculateScheduleStatistics:63
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.retrafo.solution.RoadmapToPlanSolutionTransformer.transform:49
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.LocalCalculationProcess.execute:109
  at com.radiantminds.roadmap.common.scheduling.Calculation$2.run:135
  at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call:511
  at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run:266
  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker:1142
  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run:617
  at java.lang.Thread.run:745
{noformat}

h2. Workaround 1
Make sure at least one of your epics or stories can be scheduled, which means it must have an estimation and there must be at least one team available with members providing the needed skills.

h2.Workaround 2
If workaround 1 does not work, additionally adding another release in the stream, will clear out the error in some cases

fields.summary: Jira Portfolio can not enabled

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-229].
  {panel}

In our JIRA instance we set 1d = 7h.
This setting is not considered in Portfolio, that still assumes 1d = 8h.
*This mismatch makes the "Apply updates to project" set wrong estimates in JIRA*.

For instance, if I estimate a story to 2d in Portfolio, this is applied in JIRA as 2d 2h. When I set 2d in Portofolio, I assume this means 14h, because so I set the Time Tracking setting at system level.
If not, what is the purpose of setting a system Time Tracking?
fields.summary: 1d in Portfolio may not be 1d in JIRA ?!
"Update from date" no longer pulls in JIRA Issue changes

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-322].
  {panel}

We had this problem:
- we estimate a story and create a linked issue
- the developer creates some subtasks and estimates them
- we "update from date" the plan
--> story estimation in portfolio is increased, which is good. 
- we "apply update to project"
--> the estimation on the issue is increased to the sum of original estimation and subtasks
- we "update from date" again
--> the estimation on the portfolio is now set to the sum of estimation and subtasks, which are counted double now

This feedback will repeat and increase the story estimation endlessly. Also it cannot be solved by setting the estimation on the issue to zero - after two loops there will be the same effect.

When activating the "sync" option, it seems to be even worse, as the feedback will happen more often. We had estimations going up to a few hundred hours in a day or two.
fields.summary: Estimates of Stories with estimated Subtasks increase in a feedback loop
Crash while updating back to Jira

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-356].
  {panel}

See related task JPO-190 - 'calculate release' returns a start and end date in the past.

The workaround provided by Atlassian was to enter a current or future date in the 'Earliest Start' field, which I have been doing. (I still believe that it should not be necessary for the user to manually enter an appropriate start date to get around this system error.)

I have noticed that since upgrading to Portfolio 1.9.4, when I enter an earliest start date, the dynamic release start date typically returns a date the same as the earliest start date - there seems to be little or no correlation between the calculated release start date and the number of epics (with corresponding time estimates) prioritised higher than the epic in question.

Does the prioritisation of epics actually do anything?

Please help!
fields.summary: Portfolio Kanban release date output is inaccurate

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-245].
  {panel}

To reproduce:
- add 2 work items, add a dependency
- assign to different team members, Kanban mode
- disable "Dependent story constraint"

expected: 
One item should be scheduled after the other. The description of the option is "Forces dependent stories to be placed in separate sprints.", so I dont expect this to have any effect on a Kanban schedule.

what happens:
The 2 items are scheduled at the same time, breaking the dependency
fields.summary: Option "Dependent story constraint" breaks scheduling in Kanban Mode
